Fun game, though with a few caveats. I would recommend playing on Normal or Easy as a new player to give you more leeway to get used to some of the more frustrating aspects of the game, but Hard can provide a real challenge if you're into that. If you can get past these flaws (of which there are many) this is a very classic game that will give you hours of fun, as well as give some context for Half Life 2.

This game was released in 1998 and built off a modified quake engine, so I guess the people at Valve thought it would be a good idea to give Gordon Freeman the speed of sonic the hedgehog. The controls are pretty slippery as a result of this, so you'll find yourself using the WALK key (bound to SHIFT) often, especially in platforming areas. You can also press the use key when on the ground to stop you from slipping.
Enemy AI is generally pretty good, especially when it comes to the human grunts and the vortigaunts. Headcrabs will often fall from the ceiling, and sometimes when they attack you it feels pretty cheap. Some areas (especially on the hard difficulty) feel somewhat designed for trial and error, as sometimes enemies will spawn in behind you without any warning. This can be fun, but you have to be the kind of person who's willing to die multiple times and plan a strategy. Just running around without thinking will get you killed quickly in this game, unlike Doom. There are also many secrets you might not notice on an initial playthrough, and combined with the strategy aspect this gives Half Life enormous replay value, perhaps even more than Half life 2.
